narrative.title: X Corps - 1943Q1
narrative.situation: British Corps (Armoured) deployed in North Africa during 1943Q1.
narrative.objectives: X Corps functioned as Eighth Army's armoured reserve and exploitation force during Q1 1943 Tunisia operations. Primary mission: provide mobile striking power for Montgomery's Mareth Line assault. Corps executed complex command arrangement: HQ staff seconded to New Zealand Corps to provide adequate headquarters personnel for reinforced 2nd NZ Division. On 23 March, Montgomery ordered Horrocks and X Corps HQ to take control of Tebaga Gap operations, coordinating 1st Armoured Division (reinforcing from reserve), 7th Armoured Division (transferred from XXX Corps), and New Zealand Corps for 'Left Hook' outflanking maneuver. This flexible command structure allowed Montgomery to concentrate armoured divisions for decisive breakthrough while XXX Corps conducted frontal assault pinning German reserves.
narrative.axis_objective: Hold current positions and prevent Allied breakthrough.
narrative.allied_objective: Advance and neutralize Axis defensive positions.

weather.terrain: Southern Tunisia - mixed terrain including coastal plain (Mareth Line), mountainous passes (Tebaga Gap), rocky plateau, wadis, and hills. More restrictive than open Libyan desert. Better roads and water availability. Vegetation increasing compared to desert. Terrain channelizes armoured movement through key passes and valleys.
environmental_challenges: Tebaga Gap narrow passage - restricted maneuver for armoured forces, single approach bottleneck
Wadi Zigzaoug anti-tank ditch at Mareth Line - major obstacle for XXX Corps frontal assault
Minefields extensive at Mareth Line and key passes
Terrain favors defenders - hills command valleys and passes
Restricted approaches channelize attacks through predictable routes
Rocky terrain limits off-road mobility for wheeled vehicles
Supply lines 600-800km from Tripoli - extended but manageable
Coordination challenges: X Corps HQ managing multiple divisions plus New Zealand Corps staff
Limited water sources in rocky plateau areas away from coast

special_rules: Elite armoured formations - 1st and 7th Armoured Divisions both veteran units
Desert Rats (7th Armoured) legendary North Africa combat experience
Flexible command structure - X Corps HQ could coordinate multiple corps-level operations
Sherman tank superiority - 252 Sherman tanks (M4 and M4A2 variants) vs German Panzer III/IV
Combined arms mastery - tank, motorized infantry, artillery coordination
Experienced commanders: Horrocks (X Corps), Briggs (1st Armoured), Erskine (7th Armoured)
